awd_titl_txt: NSF MRI:  Development of a Multifocus Structured Illumination Microscope
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of California, Santa Cruz to develop and construct a groundbreaking new imaging system for live 3D super-resolution microscopy and employ this instrument to study the dynamic processes of life beyond the classical resolution limit (~ 200 nm). The instrument will employ Multifocus Structured Illumination Microscopy, a transformative new imaging technique. The project team will construct and employ this powerful 3D  super-resolution imaging system in the University of California at Santa Cruz (UCSC) Life Sciences Microscopy Center in collaboration with biology research groups with an initial focus on studying chromatin dynamics. Our DNA genomes are stored in the nucleus of cells as a protein-DNA complex known as chromatin.  The basic repeating subunit of chromatin, the nucleosome, consists of a protein core with DNA wrapped twice around its outside, like thread around a spool. Our DNA genomes are organized into millions of regularly spaced nucleosomes which allow our DNA to be stored compactly and create new opportunities for regulation of gene expression.

Multifocus Structured Illumination Microscopy is designed to enable 3D imaging of chromatin in living cells at nearly physiological conditions with super-resolution capability. Using specially designed diffractive optical components, which will be custom made by the project team in one of the University of California academic nanofabrication user facilities, the microscope will simultaneously capture, on a single camera, an entire 3D volume of the biological specimen, by multiplexing and focus shifting the beam of light exiting the microscope objective. Employing fast Structured Illumination super-resolution imaging, the microscope will furthermore provide improved contrast and resolution to allow visualization of structures smaller than 200 nm, which have classically been impossible to study in living specimens. Placement of this instrument in the UCSC Life Sciences Microscopy Center ensures direct availability of new and exciting optical technology for application in biological research. The microscope will open up new fields of research, initially in chromatin dynamics, and successively also in other fields of biological research, where live 3D imaging beyond the classical limit of resolution is needed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have constructed a groundbreaking microscope that combines two cutting edge technologies; first, the ability to visualize biological samples at a resolution (small size) that is at the very limit of light microscopy; and second, the ability to rapidly obtain 3 dimensional images of those samples. 3D microscopy works by taking many images of separate thin slices of a sample and using a computer to assemble these into a single 3D image (see Figure). In the past, this was a slow and laborious process that required repeated refocusing of the microscope to obtain the multiple images needed to form the 3D image. This greatly limited the ability to obtain 3D images of living, moving objects. Our multi-focus microscope (MFM) overcomes this limitation by simultaneous imaging multiple slices through a sample. By combining high resolution microscopy with 3D imagining, we are able to see single, fluorescent molecules as they move through living cells.

 

We have used our new microscope to study gene transcription. During transcription, the enzyme RNA polymerase copies the DNA of a gene to make an RNA molecule. In the case of genes that encode proteins, this RNA copy of the gene can subsequently be read out (translated) by the ribosome to make the protein encoded by that gene. Some genes are transcribed frequently, leading to high concentrations of that RNA, whereas other genes are transcribed infrequently, leading to low levels of the RNA. A surprising observation is that the frequency of a gene’s transcription is not constant over time, even if the levels of its RNA copies are unchanging. Rather, genes are transcribed in on-off bursts. These bursts become longer and more frequent when a gene is highly expressed. Thus, to understand the details of gene expression, merely measuring the levels of RNA in a cell is not sufficient, we need to examine transcription as it occurs. 

 

By fluorescently labeling specific RNA molecules as they are made, our microscope can be used to measure how frequently a gene is transcribed and how long it takes to be completely transcribed. To date, 2 studies that used our microscope to study gene transcription have been published. The first examined gene repression. That is, how is gene transcription reduced or turned off by specific regulatory signals? Observations of gene transcription with our microscope indicated that gene repression reduced the duration of bursts of transcription. That is, when a gene is in its on state, repressors decrease how long the on state lasts, resulting in fewer RNA molecules being produced. The second study compared observations of gene expression obtained from living cells with the predictions of different models for how transcription regulators work. This analysis ruled out models in which bursts of transcription activity were due to random on-off activity. Instead, the observed data matched predictions of models in which specific, energy requiring processes are required to control rate and frequency of gene transcription.
